result.execSummary:
The defendant Joshua B Rhode was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Bail Jumping-Felony [Modifiers: Repeater], a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 946.49(1)(b).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

miscConds.notes: Maintain GFE in FTE/schooling or combination of the two and when not fully engaged, complete 10 hours of community service per week.

Absolute sobriety from drugs and alcohol. 

No contact with A.S. unless approved by agent for child care.

If probation is revoked or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.  

A copy of the police report has been electronically sent to the probation office.

Complete SAFE program intake.  Complete AODA with follow through.  Complete any assessment, treatment, counseling as deemed necessary by agent.  DNA sample.

COURT ORDERS: Ct. 1 Bail Jumping- Felony- repeater: 4 years WSPS- 2 years IC, 2 years ES, concurrent to 17CM1050 Ct. 1. Deft would be eligible for both prison programming- Challenge Incarceration & Substance Abuse. 266 days jail credit granted. CONDITIONS of ES: Any outstanding fees and costs to be paid as condition of ES. Complete AODA assessment with follow through. Complete any assessment, treatment, or counseling deemed necessary by agent. Maintain absolute sobriety from controlled substance and alcohol.

Date and time set for plea in 15CF1145, revoke DEOJ in 14CF666, and SAR in 14CF444

Ct. 2 DC- repeater >> D&RI
COURT grants above
PLEA: 
Ct. 1 BJ- Felony- repeater >> NO CONTEST
COURT advises def of rights (including constitutional rights) & penalties & ques def to understanding.  
COURT finds plea & waiver of rights freely & vol made, a factual basis & def guilty. 
COURT ORDERS: w/hold sentencing. 4 years probation for each count on 14CF444 Ct. 2- Battery- repeater- domestic abuse & 15CF1145 Ct. 1 BJ- Felony- repeater. CONDITIONS: Complete SAFE program intake. Complete AODA assessment with follow through. Absolute sobriety from drugs and alcohol. No contact with A.S., unless approved by agent for child care. Compelete any assessment, counseling, or treatment deemed necessary by agent. Maintain GFE in full time employment/schooling/combination of the two, when not fully engaged complete 10 hours of community service per week. Pay CC. Pay DNA sample and surcharge. 

14CF444 SAR:
State requesting 9 months MCJ and mentions deft is still on probation in 14CF666 on Ct. 3, 4, and 6
Atty Renc in agreement and is requesting huber release for work, school, or child care
COURT ORDERS: 14CF444 Ct. 2 Battery- repeater- domestic abuse: Serve 9 months MCJ. 62 days credit served. Can be served with huber release for work, school, treatment if meets jail criteria. Huber may include up to 4 hours of time to move property from ACE Hardware.

records.addlTxt: No contact with victim(s): T.E. Contact includes direct personal or physical and indirect contact by phone, in writing of any kind, entry to the person's residence or place of employment together with contacts through other persons.  Contact, however, may be made through the defendant's attorney. No alcohol. No bars, taverns, liquor stores, or beer tents.
